transcription.text: Hello everyone, my name is Jenna and I work with Melonport and I'm here today to tell
you that Melonport will not exist by Defcon 5.
So I would like to start with a quick question to the audience, who knew already before that
Melonport would not stick around for a couple more years?
One, two, three, this is the Melonport team, okay.
So not so many.
That's normal because Melonport is actually one of the first DEP protocol which is going
to wind down the company that built it after two years of development and completely let
go of the control of the protocol.
So really Melonport is a Swiss-based company that was mandated in February 2017 for the
development of the Melon protocol and Melonport took the commitment to wind down the
company once the protocol would be ready to deploy it on the mainnet.
So in February 2019, which is two years later, in a couple of months from now, we are going
to deploy it to the mainnet, wind down the company and decentralize the governance and
future maintenance of the protocol.
So really what this presentation is about is how can we get rid of Melonport?
Or in other words, how do we make it so that the Melon protocol can be self-sustainable
and succeed without the existence of the company that initially built it?
So this is threefold.
The first part we are going to talk about how can we create a healthy ground for network
effects.
Then we are going to see how do we provide the proper economic incentives for the participants
in the network and the third part is the governance and maintenance framework that we put in
place to support the future of the Melon protocol.
So first, what is Melon?
I'm going to give a quick Melon 101 for the people not familiar with the Melon protocol.
So Melon is an open source protocol for on-chain asset management.
It allows anyone to set up and manage a fund on the Ethereum blockchain.
So technically what it is, it is a set of rules implementing the behavior of an investment
fund as a set of smart contracts.
So another way to understand what Melon is is to see how you would actually create a
fund on our platform.
So it's very simple.
It takes a few seconds.
You go on the platform, give your fund a name, select the exchanges that you want your
fund to be allowed to trade with, then you are going to be able to define your fee structure
so that is the management and performance fee are your funds.
So just as in the traditional world except that here this is encoded in the smart contracts,
then you will also have the possibility to configure your risk management profiles.
So those are pre-trade clearance rules that are going to be encoded in the smart contracts
and enforced by the blockchain.
So it can be maximum number of positions, it could be price tolerance, maximum concentration,
you could have, you could wait list assets, you could wait list assets if you want to give
the guarantee to your investors that you are not going to trade anything dodgy.
And then really you are going to have the overview of the rule set that you defined.
And as soon as you hit create funds, you are actually going to be deploying a fund to the
Ethereum blockchain.
So really on the blockchain, how does it look like?
You get what we call a technology regulated and operated funds.
So it is a set of smart contracts.
And each contract is a component of the funds.
So you have a component that takes care of the internal accounting and nav calculation.
You have a component that takes care of the fee calculation and distribution.
You have a component that takes care of the trading, etc., etc.
So you as a fund manager on top, you control your funds and can make various interactions
such as trading on behalf of your investors.
So you can have external investors on the left that can come in and directly invest in
your fund by calling a function in the participation component.
And the valuation of your fund is going to be calculated on chain using on chain prices
that we get from the cable network.
And then the other external interaction that you have are the decentralized exchanges that
you can trade with.
So right now we have integrated Oasis decks, zero X and cable and we have the S/VNX integration
coming up soon.
So that is how a fund looks like on the blockchain.
And what I think is really nice is that in the past two years we have seen an explosion
of open source finance protocols.
And Mellon comes nicely on top of that and nicely integrates and connects those different
protocols.
So Mellon allows you to manage crypto assets, trade on decentralized exchanges.
In the future we envision integration with credit, lending, on-chain, margin, derivatives,
all those type of new protocols that we have seen.
And we have also people working on blockchain-based identity systems which is really important
if you want to be able to identify the investors in your fund.
So that is for the Mellon 101.
So now we can actually get into the subject of today.
So when we design a system that needs to be self-sustainable and decentralized, what
you really want to do is identify the different stakeholders that you have in your network.
And make sure that your model caters to the needs of each of your stakeholders.
So for in our case we have a couple of stakeholders and they are the token holders, the project
and developers who build on top of Mellon.
We have the users and we have the maintainers, the people who are going to make decisions
in the future for the protocol.
So throughout this presentation we're going to see how we make sure that we cater to the
needs of all of those stakeholders.
So first of all we want to be able to maximize the network effects.
In the past couple of months we have seen more and more projects reaching out to us,
projects and team wanting to build new things on top of Mellon.
And that is really cool.
It doesn't really come as a surprise to us because asset management has a lot of use
cases.
We are focusing on the hedge fund use case but you can have VC funds, pension funds, insurance
funds, we also have people working on the gamification of asset management.
And it's really nice but the problem is that each of these projects needs to get funding
and what they plan to do rightfully so is to run another ICO to get funding.
And what you get with that is that you get different projects sharing the same underlying
infrastructure but each of that project has a token, a token economy, a different governance
system, a different maintenance system.
So you have one infrastructure but isolated sub-ecosystems.
And that we believe is not great because we think isolation brings inefficiencies.
So if we find a way to actually have synergies between those projects and to make it so that
they can share more than just the infrastructure, we believe that all of our ecosystem could
benefit from economies of scale.
So earlier this year we decided to open up the Mellon token to other teams and other
projects in order to benefit from synergies.
So basically the Mellon token has a yearly inflation fee which is a fixed amount of token
that gets minted each year and this inflation pool is going to be used to fund different
things.
So the first thing is compensating developers who complete MAPs which are Mellon improvement
proposal inspired by the Ethereum EIPs.
So if you're a developer and you see that there is this feature like yeah I think this
is cool, I want to solve that problem or I want to make this integration, you can do
it and get compensated in Mellon for that.
The second thing is for a project who want to build on Mellon and who need to get funding,
instead of doing an ICO what they could do is make a funding request to the Mellon governance
system and if the governance system agrees that they could get their funding through
the Mellon inflation pool.
And the third thing is a little bit more exotic I would say and maybe a little bit more forward
thinking, those are token swaps and token mergers, inspired by what happened very often
in the traditional investment banking world.
So in the case of the token swap it would be the case where you have a project that already
has a token and we identify potential synergies between Mellon and that other project.
If that other project has a smaller market cap than Mellon what we could do provided that
both governance systems pre-agree to it, this project could burn all of their token and
in exchange they could get Mellon token and we kind of like join forces between the two
project and create a stronger and bigger ecosystem.
And the last thing is the token merger request, so that is the case that you have another
project that has another token but it's like a project of a similar size, similar market
cap.
So in this case this would not require anything from the inflation actually, it would just
require both projects to actually burn their tokens in order to create a new token that
encompasses both economies and both communities.
So opening up the Mellon token allows us to benefit from synergies but also to align the
interests of the participants across the networks.
So this part caters to the needs of the project and developers that build on top of Mellon.
So now that we have seen how to maximize network effects we actually compensate people with
Mellon tokens we need to make sure that we build in the right economic mechanism in the
token so that the token is actually something that is desirable from those developers.
Today is providing proper economic incentives.
So this relates to the token economic design.
So when we were working on that we really had three goals in mind that we wanted to
fulfill.
So the first one was ensuring that the Mellon token would be desirable and would have integrity
in order to be able to provide proper economic incentives to the user and developer needs
of the network.
And last but not least we also wanted to avoid the pitfalls of the high velocity token model
which is a problem that has been written a lot about by different people such as Vitalik
or Chris Bronesky or others.
We published a very long and detailed blog on that if you are interested on that part.
So with these goals in mind our solution to the token economics is called the Mellon
and Jane.
So let's take just a step back.
When you use when you interact with a smart contract on Ethereum you pay you pay gas to
the Ethereum network and that gas is calculated as the number of gas units that are consumed
by the function that you're calling and that is multiplied by the Ethereum gas price.
So we came up with the idea that when you interact with Mellon smart contracts in addition
to paying gas to the Ethereum network you're also going to pay what we call the asset management
gas and you're going to pay that to the Mellon network.
So the way it's calculated is very similar to how it's done on Ethereum.
So we take the same number of gas units that are consumed by the function on the EVM and
instead of multiplying that by the Ethereum gas price we multiply it by the Mellon gas
price or the asset management gas price.
So how does it look in more details?
So you're a user and you're about to use some Mellon smart contracts on Ethereum.
So we impose that asset management gas on certain functions, not all of them because
we want to say cheap, affordable and competitive compared to other alternatives.
So on a few functions you're going to pay your gas to the Ethereum network as usual.
And in addition to that you're also going to pay your asset management gas to the Mellon
network.
And instead of paying that gas, and this is really important here, instead of paying
that gas in Mellon you're going to pay that gas, the asset management gas in Ether.
That Ether is sent to the Mellon engine smart contract and that contract is very simple.
It only does two things.
The first thing is that when it receives Ether from the user interaction it's going
to sell this Ether and buy Mellon at a premium on the market.
So it's basically a contract that is a uni-directional liquidity contract.
It's a contract that is a market itself.
So it's going to sell the ETH by Mellon at a premium and once it has Mellon in the contract
it's just going to burn those Mellon.
So sending them to a probably inaccessible address, you know how that works.
So what we have here is that when the network is used absent inflation, the Mellon total
supply is going to be decreasing.
So this mechanism gives us two very nice things.
The first thing is we manage to reduce friction, inconvenience and costs on the user because
instead of having to own Mellon and Ether when you use Mellon on Ethereum, you only need
it as a user to have Ether just as if you were using any smart contract in Ethereum.
And the second thing and arguably much more important is that we manage to align the token
value with the usage of the network.
And we do that without having a high-velocity token model.
So that's really important.
We think that we're the first DAP protocol to have managed to do something like that.
So we are very proud of our work there and I encourage anyone who is interested to read
the Mellon mix two piece that we wrote about that.
So that part as you might have understood by now takes care of the token holders.
So it seems like the token holders are interested by the return on investment on the token.
And if the network is successful, this mechanism should cater to the needs of the token holders
and please them.
So now that we've seen how to maximize network effects and to provide proper economic incentives,
the last part that we need to go through is the governance and maintenance system of
Mellon.
So when Mellon Port is going to disappear in February 2019, we need to have a way to make
decisions for the future of the protocol.
So that's what we're going to see now.
So first of all, when designing the system, we really ask ourselves, okay, why are we
doing that?
Like, what are the goals that we want this governance model to complete, basically?
So those are three-fold as well.
So the first one is that we want to preserve the integrity and security of the network.
This is extremely important when you're speaking about asset management.
The second thing is that we want to maximize user adoption and protect the user as much
as possible.
And the third thing is that we want to foster innovation in order to make the network more
attractive.
So how do we do that?
So when I talked about our different stakeholders in this space, we're going to talk about this
again now.
So when you're building a governance model, I think that really what you want to do is
identify what is the most vulnerable stakeholder group in your ecosystem.
And so that's how we worked.
Our most vulnerable group are the users here.
So the users are the people who manage Mellon funds, so asset managers, and also the investors
who are invested in those Mellon funds.
So from this assumption that the users are the most vulnerable, we worked out a model
that is user-centric, so we focused on protecting the user, but also making sure that their
voices are heard, and will be heard in the future.
And we also wanted to make sure that the users would be supported by technically skilled
people.
So we come up with a user-centric and skill-based governance model.
So how does that look?
So I introduced you to the Mellon Council now.
So the Mellon Council is a body that is going to be responsible for the future development
and maintenance of the Mellon Protocol.
It is composed of two subgroups.
The first one is the Mellon Technical Council.
So this is a group of technically skilled people, or people who have expertise on the
Mellon Protocol or other finance-related protocols on Ethereum, or people who have contributed
to the Mellon code base in the past.
So this subgroup is going to be responsible for the technical parts of the decisions that
we're going to have to make in the future.
The second subgroup is what we call the MEB representatives.
So those are the Mellon Exposed Businesses.
So this is a self-organized entity where you will have all of the users who can prove
that they are users of the network, either by proving that they have asset under management,
subsequent asset under management on Mellon, or proving that they have used this amount
of asset management gas over the past year.
So this group is going to be able to elect among themselves their representatives to sit
on the Mellon Council together with the Mellon Technical Council members.
So with this Mellon Council, what we hope to achieve is that by combining the user representation
and people who are technically skilled and informed, we hope that we are able to make
the best decisions possible for the protocol and for the users of Mellon.
So how does that work?
How does-- how do we form the Council?
So I told you how the Mellon Exposed Businesses is formed.
For the Mellon Technical Council, it's a little bit different.
So in February 2019, Mellon Port is going to assign 5 to 7 seats for the Mellon Technical
Council to external people, to people that we believe have the skills or expertise to
do that and also the ethical standards that go with it.
So we're going to assign the initial seats.
And then from there on, the Council is going to be able to self-expense, so to grow by
itself, based on the consensus of its members, following a 5 to 2 ratios.
So for five Mellon Technical Council members will be able to have two MMB representatives.
It's worth noting here that the Mellon Technical Council are going to be compensated with Mellon
token from the inflation pool that are going to be invested over a couple of years.
And that those people are unknown.
So we know who they are.
Their identities are revealed.
So now what is-- what are the responsibilities of that Council?
You might be wondering.
So those are three also.
The first one are protocol upgrades.
The Mellon code base will need to evolve from February onwards.
So the Mellon Council is going to be responsible for deploying new contracts and most importantly
managing the ENS subdomain names that point to the official Mellon contracts.
Important to note here, all upgrades are obtained only, which means that the user will never
be forced into an upgrade and it will require explicit and voluntary action from the user
to upgrade to new contracts.
So the second thing are resource allocation.
So as I mentioned in the beginning of the presentation, we have the inflation pool, which
can be used for various things.
And the Mellon Council is going to be responsible for making decisions as to what to fund or
not, which project to accept in as a funding request or token swap or merger, et cetera.
So that's going to be a Mellon Council responsibility.
And the last one are network parameters.
So when I presented the Mellon engine, I mentioned the asset management gas price.
And what I didn't say is that this is actually a variable that we can change and that we
can adjust.
So based on our financial modeling, it is not expected that this asset management gas
price would need to change very often.
Actually, I think it would be quite rare because it is expected that market dynamics
will make natural adjustments.
But we can't predict -- there are some scenarios that we can't really predict.
So we want to have the option to adjust the gas price basically to reduce it in two cases.
The first one is if there is a network usage spike overnight, you might want to reduce
the gas price.
And the second one is market volatility.
So here we're exposed to the Mellon ETH price, but also the ETH USD price.
So the Mellon USD price.
And if there is extreme market conditions or volatility, you might want to reduce the
asset management gas price in order to stay affordable for the user and competitive compared
to other alternatives.
So that part, under governance, caters to the maintainers of the network and to the users
as you might have understood by now.
So to wrap up, our model, both token economic and governance, addresses the needs of all
of the stakeholders.
We maximize network effect by opening up the Mellon token so that we can align interest,
participant interest across the network.
And we managed to have a token model that is aligning the token value with the usage
of the network.
And finally, we recognize that the users are the most important, really the key player in
our ecosystem without users at the end of the day, we fail.
So we designed a system that makes sure that the users are valued properly and supported
by technical skills.
So with that, I would like to announce that the Mellon Technical Council applications
start today.
So really, the technical council is supposed to be inclusive and open.
So if they are excellent developers who have the skills or feel like competent for that
role, we would be really happy to receive applications.
So you can reach out to MTC@melanport.com.
But all of the Mellon Team is here.
Everyone is wearing leather jackets.
So if you want to reach out in person, use DevCon for that.
We would be very happy as well.
So this was the last Mellon Port presentation.
It was another for me to do that.
Mellon Port will not exist by DevCon 5, but that doesn't mean that it's the end of Mellon.
It's actually just the beginning, I believe.
So thank you.
And I think we can upload the Mellon Team for the incredible work to make this a reality.
Thank you.
[BLANK_AUDIO]
[BLANK_AUDIO]
[BLANK_AUDIO]
